messages.content: I was formerly paying for the health insurance my company offered. I decided to cancel the health insurance. According to a letter I received from the insurance provider, I am no longer covered as of April 30. I just received a paycheck for the pay period from May 1 to May 14. On this paycheck, pre-tax dollars were still deducted for health insurance. I was thinking this would not be the case, since I was no longer covered as of April 30, and the pay period beginning was May 1. Please explain possible reasons why I may have had money deducted for health insurance from this paycheck, and possible solutions if I need to take any action.

There are a few possible reasons why health insurance premiums may have still been deducted from your May 1-14 paycheck, even though your coverage ended on April 30:

1. Administrative delay: There may have been a delay in processing your cancellation request and updating your payroll records. It can take time for the changes to filter through the various administrative systems. Your employer's payroll department may not have received or processed the notification that your coverage ended on April 30 before running the May 1-14 payroll.

2. Payroll cycle mismatch: Your employer's payroll cycle may be different from your insurance coverage period. For example, your coverage may be month-to-month starting on the 1st, but your employer's payroll cycle may run from the 15th to the 14th of each month. So the May 1-14 paycheck was already "locked in" before your April 30 cancellation took effect. 

3. Policy to deduct for full pay period: Your employer may have a policy to deduct insurance premiums for an entire pay period, even if coverage does not span the full period. Some employers take this approach for administrative simplicity.

In any of these cases, you should contact your employer's payroll department and insurance provider to notify them of the incorrect deduction and request a refund. Provide the details of your coverage cancellation date and the erroneous deduction from your May 1-14 paycheck. They should then issue you a refund for the amount incorrectly deducted.

Going forward, verify with the payroll department that no further insurance deductions will be taken from your paychecks, now that you are no longer enrolled in the company's health insurance plan. Let me know if you have any other questions!

Please write an email to the HR representative of my company explaining that money was still deducted from my paycheck for the May 1st to May 14th pay period, even though I would not expect this due to my insurance being canceled as of April 30th. Please write it as though I am speaking to a single woman, who I have communicated with before. In places where this woman's name would be used, please write the characters inside the following quotes: "INSERT_NAME_HERE". Please use a respectful tone.

Here is a draft:

Dear "INSERT_NAME_HERE",

I hope this email finds you well. I wanted to follow up on the cancellation of my health insurance coverage through the company plan. According to the letter I received from the insurance provider, my coverage ended effective April 30. However, I noticed that my paycheck for the pay period of May 1 through May 14 still had deductions for health insurance premiums. 

Given that my coverage ended on April 30, I did not expect to see these deductions from the May 1 paycheck. I understand there are a few possible reasons this may have happened, such as a delay in processing the change in coverage or differences in the payroll and coverage cycles. However, I wanted to bring this to your attention in case the payroll records need to be updated and to request a refund of the amounts incorrectly deducted.

Please let me know if there are any steps I need to take to ensure future paychecks do not have deductions for insurance coverage I no longer have. I appreciate your help in resolving this issue.

Thank you in advance for your help and please let me know if you need any further information from me.

Best regards,
[Your name]
Please give me an example title for this email.

Here is an example title for the email:

Incorrect Health Insurance Deductions from May 1 Paycheck

Please give me an example title that indicates it's a follow up, and does not suggest any wrongdoing on the company's part. For example, the word "incorrect" may suggest to the company that they did something negligent.

Got it, I understand. Here is an alternative title that frames this as a follow up while avoiding an implication of error or wrongdoing:

Follow Up on Cancellation of Health Insurance Coverage
